div1.head: Jim to Mlle. Marcelle Guerin June 7th 1915
div1.p: I have just received your letter inclosing [sic] the clipping, ^ re Pont a Mousson and many thanks. I have too heard from Paul and he has given me the new of Kiffin. My friend Thierry-Delauoue who used to get letters from the Vicomte du Peloux with news for me of Rockwell, got his in a recent bombardment and it fell to me to evacuate him.

So old Russia has returned to the attack has he? I should think you ought to be able to get him to go to war and then he might get killed and your troubles would be over. He’s certainly a persistent individual.

I got into Nancy yesterday for the first time I’ve been at the front. I had a whole hour and as I was with an officer who insisted on taking me around in a sea going [???] hack and pointing out the sights I had a very good tour of the place. It was a glorious day and I enjoyed it all immensely. The Place d’Alliance is a perfect little gem. The gardens, where we sat down to have a drink— I would have you know that for a month now I have touched but lemonade and other soft thirst killers—were beautiful. It was Sunday and everyone was out strolling around. True there was something strange about the scene; the noticeable absence of men from twenty to forty, but but [sic] never for a moment could one realize that the greatest war in history was being fought twenty eight kilometers distant. Returning to our quarters was very interesting following the peace and quiet of Nancy. I took an artillery captain back with me and as it was his first time at our part of the front the details of approach to the line were called to new attention by his questions.
and comments. At five fifteen we left the beautiful city in the quiet of its Sunday rest and at six we were in front of artillery that was in action. After we had followed the road for a few kilometers the captain called attention to an observation balloon, sharply outlined against the deep blue sky. Then we went thru [sic] villages where great crowds of soldiers were gathered. As we passed others one could notice the difference in the appearance of the men. Those in the towns farther back were cleaner and looked fresh; as we went on one could notice boots and coats still covered with the dirt of the trenches and then we arrived at a town where the fronts of some buildings were torn by eclats. We rolled on and suddenly came to a stretch of road on which the Germans can look and frequently shell. The captain covered his gold galons with a map he was looking at. We then entered a town where I began to meet friends. They greeted us and some wanted a ride. Then we came to our town and its wrecks of buildings. We turned out towards the trenches; past cantonments where great numbers of soldiers I knew where resting. They would wave, and in the most advanced one a man ran up, stopped me, and gave me a ring he’d been making for me out of a piece of shell. “Why you know everyone here don’t you?” said the officer. We had been hearing distant firing but now it became clear and sharp and we looked for wires that having been cut by shells might be too low to pass under. Up we went. There were no soldiers to be seen now and ahead we heard heavy firing. We rounded a bend and came upon a battery firing across the road just in
front of us. Of course we could go no further of course and so our dapper little captain with the usual profuse thanks dismounted and disappeared in the woods behind to circle the artillery. I couldn’t quite get it thru [sic] my head that only three quarters of an hour before we had slipped out of a peaceful city. The changes are rapid. Even with the people. The officer chap was quite stiff and formal when we started from Nancy and he reminded me strongly of your Paris fighting men. As we neared the front he began to get more chummy and when he got out of the car in front of the guns he was calling me “mon vieux” and wishing “Bonne chance” and various other friendly farewells.
This letter has been written in sections. Every time I get started along comes a call and I have to up and away, and its an hour or more before I can get back to finish it up.
By the way Miss Fuller [sp?] is not coming over. She lost her nerve, or at least gives it as an excuse, that the liners are being sunk, and she’s loath to die or take a chance on it at the present.
I had a man in my car just now that had come within the zone of effect of an asphyxiating, or however you spell it, shell. he suffered in his breathing and —Next day

At this moment one of the doctors came up to ask me where he could get ahold [sic] of Salisbury. I was stationed for the day on call at Ambulance ['m' lined through] 1 and was writing this letter in the court- yard. The doctor had just sat down next to me when we heard the tearing roar of a great shell overhead. It hit a house a hundred yards from us with a deafening explosion. We bent down to avoid the eclats. I asked the doctor what message I could carry to Salisbury. Instead of replying he got up and said “Come in
with me.” We entered the long corridor. A few seconds, not more than three I estimate, afterwards, I saw a small group of brancardiers, in the next entrance to the corridor from us, crouch swiftly down. They had heard the whistle. Immediately the air became crushing. I was bent over. There was an overpowering detonation and it became dark. Glass, wood and plaster pelted and fell on me. I remember wondering what was coming down next and then I heard terrible shrieks above the din of falling debris. I tried to look down the corridor thru [sic] the dense smoke and saw a man waving his arms and yelling crazily totter towards me. He grabbed my shoulder and moaned. You have heard a child cry after some shock. It was like that but this was a man and it made it seem worse. The clouds of smoke and dust cleared and twenty yards from me I saw one of the brancardiers on the floor. A stream of red blood was feeling its way thru [sic] the coating of dust on the floor. An eclat had passed through his chest. He had been killed instantly. Others were wounded. I went out and saw the great hole where the “marmite” had struck twenty five yards from where I was standing. The eclats had wrecked the front of the building. If it had been ten feet nearer it would have hit the corridor wall and bagged the whole bunch of us. I heard another coming and fell flat on my face as we do to avoid them. It passed over. The men began hurrying towards the cave. I had never yet taken to any but when I saw an officer with the Medaille Militaire scurry down I figured it would be all right and joined the basement crowd. First I went back to get this letter that I had placed on a chair in the corridor when I entered and found it all covered with glass and stones and plaster. I’ve cleaned it up as well as I can. The rough edges come from cramming it
in my pocket. I’m sorry. Shells began coming over at regular intervals. When it was time to go back to the caserne I waited until a shell went off and then made a dash for it. Got to the main street and was tangled up in broken telephone lines. I got them off and hit it up across the Place. Two of our fellows who were looking out from a sand bag shelter there said I just got away in time to miss two. After supper we went down to see the shells that were being aimed at the bridge. They came from such a long distance that one couldn’t hear the guns. We could hear them go overhead. See a couple of columns of water hurtle a hundred feet into the air and then the twin crashes. The shells came in pairs. Then we’d run for a wall in order to dodge the eclats. After that there would be a scramble for them.
There were a great many killed yesterday and several wounded. 60 casualties in all.

We evacuated all the hospitals in Pont a Mousson last night and it was eleven before we finished. It was pretty working then for we could see a part of the town burning from the bombard- ment and shrapnel bursting over to keep people from putting it out. I stayed on call at the caserne and read your sweet letter of May 27th that came only last night. I had only a lantern for the bombardment broke our gas system as it had the electric before. Do you really mean to tell me you would care especially if I were killed and that it would relieve you in anyway to get news of me frequently? I wish I could believe it. I naturally do not care especially about getting killed but if I do I hope its up on service at the postes back of the trenches and not in town during bombardments. I dislike the idea. Up at Clos Blois Montanville where we’re under fire its quite
interesting and enjoyable. Its part of the game and in the fight. I’m going up there now in an hour for an attack is in progress, and the wounded will be coming down from the trenches then. Shells are singing overhead and explosions are shaking my room but that doesn’t bother us for its only our artillery shooting and the Germans shooting back at the batteries. Its a fearful din tho. [sic]

I got a nice call down yesterday but I was mad and didn’t give a rap about rules. A few of the fat, good for nothing doctors at Amb 1 asked me to take them to Montanville to see Poincaire who had come up. That was all right but after they had finished their visit instead of going back they went into a popote and proceeded to tank up. I had to wait. In an hour they came out singing Tipperary and feeling fine. I thought it would be fun to scare them and ran them down the outside road on which the Germans can look and over which they fire shrapnel. They discovered where they were too late to take another road, and the singing ceased. Just my luck. The Boches didn’t pay any attention to the load of officers even tho [sic] they did to one that Lovell was running towards Dieulouard the other day and banged a shell over at them. I got a call by the Docs all right but when the Medicine Divisionaire found out about the joy ride, they came in for theirs all right. One of the fat ones was wounded slightly next to me in the bombardment that followed.
I’m sending this letter into Paris by a refugee to be mailed to you from there.
